tasks.title: Setup Project Repository
tasks.description: Initialize the project repository with version control and basic project structure.
tasks.details: Create a new Git repository for the project. Set up the basic directory structure for frontend and backend components. Initialize package managers for frontend (npm/yarn) and backend (pipenv/virtualenv).
tasks.testStrategy: Verify that the repository is accessible and the initial structure is correctly set up by cloning and running basic commands.

subtasks.title: Initialize Git repository and remote
subtasks.description: Create the project root, initialize a Git repository with main branch, add baseline files (.gitignore, README, LICENSE), create/connect a remote repository, make the initial commit, and push.
subtasks.details:
- Create project directory and initialize Git: mkdir <project-name> && cd <project-name> && git init -b main
- Create baseline files:
  - README.md: include project name, summary, and high-level structure goals
  - LICENSE: choose MIT or appropriate license
  - .gitignore: include common Node, Python, and OS ignores (e.g., node_modules/, dist/, build/, .venv/, __pycache__/, .DS_Store, .env, .pytest_cache/)
  - .gitattributes: text=auto eol=lf (optional)
- Create and connect remote repo:
  - Using GitHub CLI: gh repo create <org-or-user>/<repo> --public --source=. --remote=origin --push
  - Or create manually on hosting provider, then: git remote add origin git@github.com:<org-or-user>/<repo>.git
- First commit and push: git add . && git commit -m "chore: initial repository setup" && git push -u origin main
- Configure repository settings (optional): default branch main, protect main branch, require PR reviews.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run git remote -v to confirm remote connection. Visit the remote host to verify the repository exists and initial files are present. Optionally git clone <repo-url> ../tmp-clone and verify contents.

subtasks.title: Create base project directory structure
subtasks.description: Establish a clear directory layout for frontend, backend, and project support assets to scaffold subsequent work.
subtasks.details:
- Create directories: mkdir -p frontend src placeholder if needed; mkdir -p backend; mkdir -p docs; mkdir -p scripts; mkdir -p .github/workflows
- Add placeholder files so empty dirs are tracked: touch frontend/README.md backend/README.md docs/README.md scripts/README.md
- Add an .editorconfig at repo root to enforce consistency (e.g., root=true; indent_size=2; end_of_line=lf; insert_final_newline=true)
- Update README.md with a short directory layout section and contribution/getting started notes
- Commit: git add . && git commit -m "chore: scaffold base project structure" && git push
subtasks.testStrategy: List files (e.g., tree -a -L 2 or ls -la) and verify directories exist and are tracked. Confirm README includes the structure overview.

subtasks.title: Initialize frontend package manager (npm) and baseline configs
subtasks.description: Set up Node.js tooling for the frontend with npm, add minimal lint/format configuration, and create placeholder source structure.
subtasks.testStrategy: From frontend/: run npm install to ensure dependencies install; run npm run lint and npm run format:check to confirm tooling works. Confirm src/index.js exists and no lint errors are reported.

subtasks.title: Initialize backend Python environment (pipenv) and baseline structure
subtasks.description: Set up Python virtual environment with pipenv for the backend and create a minimal backend scaffolding.
subtasks.details:
- Ensure Python 3.11+ is available (e.g., pyenv install 3.11.x && pyenv local 3.11.x in backend/ if using pyenv)
- Initialize pipenv in backend: cd backend && pipenv --python 3.11
- Optionally add dev tools: pipenv install --dev black flake8 isort
- Create basic structure: mkdir -p src/app && touch src/app/__init__.py && echo "print('backend initialized')" > src/app/main.py
- Create config files (optional but recommended):
  - .flake8 with basic rules (e.g., [flake8] max-line-length = 100; extend-ignore = E203,W503)
  - pyproject.toml for Black/isort configuration (e.g., [tool.black] line-length = 100; [tool.isort] profile = "black")
  - .env.example with placeholders (e.g., FLASK_ENV=development; DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:pass@localhost:5432/db)
- Add basic Makefile in backend/ with recipes: install (pipenv install --dev), fmt (pipenv run black . && pipenv run isort .), lint (pipenv run flake8)
- Commit: git add . && git commit -m "chore(backend): initialize pipenv and baseline structure" && git push
subtasks.testStrategy: From backend/: run pipenv run python src/app/main.py and verify output. If dev tools installed, run pipenv run black --version and pipenv run flake8 to confirm they execute.

subtasks.title: Configure pre-commit hooks and CI, then validate by cloning
subtasks.description: Add repository-wide pre-commit hooks for basic hygiene and a CI workflow to verify installs for frontend and backend. Validate setup by cloning and running basic commands.
subtasks.details:
- Pre-commit setup (root):
  - If using pipenv, install: cd backend && pipenv install --dev pre-commit && cd ..
  - Create .pre-commit-config.yaml at repo root with hooks: trailing-whitespace, end-of-file-fixer, check-yaml, check-merge-conflict, mixed-line-ending; plus language-specific (optional): black, isort (repo: psf/black, PyCQA/isort), flake8; prettier (repo: pre-commit/mirrors-prettier, target frontend files)
  - Install hooks: pre-commit install (run via pipenv: pipenv run pre-commit install from backend/ or use a global pre-commit install)
- CI setup (GitHub Actions): create .github/workflows/ci.yml with two jobs on push/pull_request:
  - frontend job: actions/setup-node@v4 (lts), working-directory: frontend, run: npm ci || npm install, then npm run lint and npm run format:check
  - backend job: actions/setup-python@v5 (3.11), install pipenv, working-directory: backend, run: pipenv --python 3.11 && pipenv install --dev, then optional lint (pipenv run flake8)
- Update README with CI status badge and local development instructions (frontend and backend basic commands)
- Final validation by cloning fresh:
  - In a separate directory: git clone <repo-url> fresh-clone && cd fresh-clone
  - Run frontend check: cd frontend && npm install && npm run lint && cd ..
  - Run backend check: cd backend && pipenv install --dev && pipenv run python src/app/main.py && cd ..
  - Run pre-commit across repo: (from backend/) pipenv run pre-commit run --all-files
subtasks.testStrategy: Open a pull request to trigger CI and confirm both jobs pass. Locally, verify pre-commit blocks malformed changes. Validate a fresh clone can install and run the basic commands without errors.

subtasks.title: Configure .gitignore, .gitattributes, and .editorconfig
subtasks.description: Add standard ignore rules and text/line-ending normalization to ensure a clean, cross-platform repository.
subtasks.details: Create a root-level .gitignore covering Python (.venv, venv, __pycache__, *.pyc, .pytest_cache, .mypy_cache, coverage/), Node (node_modules/, dist/, build/, .next/, coverage/), IDE/OS (.DS_Store, .idea/, .vscode/), env files (.env, .env.*), logs (*.log), and lockfiles as needed; add .gitattributes to enforce text eol=lf by default, mark common binaries (e.g., *.png, *.jpg, *.pdf) as binary, and set linguist settings if needed; add .editorconfig to standardize indentation (2 spaces for JS/TS/JSON/YAML, 4 spaces for Python), UTF-8, LF line endings, final newline, and trimming trailing whitespace.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run `git check-ignore -v` on representative files to confirm ignore coverage; stage files with `git add -A` and verify no unwanted artifacts are tracked; confirm line endings with `git ls-files --eol`; ensure editors pick up .editorconfig by saving sample files.

subtasks.title: Initialize repository documentation and policies
subtasks.description: Create foundational repo docs and community health files to guide contributors and clarify licensing.
subtasks.details: Add README.md with project overview, architecture layout (frontend/backend), quick start, and development scripts; choose and add LICENSE (e.g., MIT) and note year/owner; add CONTRIBUTING.md (branching strategy, Conventional Commits, code style, PR process), CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, and SECURITY.md (vulnerability reporting); create CHANGELOG.md with Keep a Changelog format; add .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE (bug_report.yml, feature_request.yml) and .github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md; include status badges placeholders for CI and coverage.
subtasks.testStrategy: Preview README locally to verify sections render; run a markdown linter (e.g., markdownlint) to ensure formatting; check that GitHub recognizes the license and templates by attempting to open a new issue/PR; verify links with a link checker.

subtasks.title: Create environment templates and bootstrap scripts
subtasks.description: Provide reproducible setup via env templates and scripted bootstrapping for frontend and backend.
subtasks.details: Add backend/.env.example (e.g., DATABASE_URL, JWT_SECRET, FLASK_ENV) and frontend/.env.example (e.g., VITE_API_BASE_URL or NEXT_PUBLIC_API_BASE_URL); add .nvmrc (Node 20.x) and .python-version (e.g., 3.11) for tooling consistency; create Makefile (or Taskfile) with targets: setup, backend.install, frontend.install, lint, format, test, run, clean; add scripts/bootstrap.sh (POSIX) and scripts/bootstrap.ps1 (Windows) to install Python env (virtualenv/pipenv), Node deps (npm ci or yarn install), and pre-commit; ensure package.json scripts exist for lint/test/build in frontend; commit lockfiles (Pipfile.lock/poetry.lock; package-lock.json/yarn.lock) if applicable.
subtasks.testStrategy: From a fresh clone, run the bootstrap or `make setup` and verify: Python env created, dependencies installed, Node deps installed, and pre-commit installed; copy .env.example to .env for both apps and confirm commands `make lint` and `make test` run without errors; confirm Node and Python versions via the files are honored.

subtasks.title: Set up code quality and git hooks (pre-commit, linters, formatters, secret scan)
subtasks.description: Configure automated formatting, linting, type checks, and secret scanning enforced via git hooks.
subtasks.details: Add .pre-commit-config.yaml with hooks: black, isort, ruff or flake8, trailing-whitespace, end-of-file-fixer, detect-secrets; configure pyproject.toml for black/isort/ruff settings; for frontend, add ESLint (.eslintrc) and Prettier (.prettierrc) with compatible rules; add npm scripts `lint`, `format`, and `lint:fix`; integrate commit message linting using @commitlint/config-conventional with a commit-msg hook (via pre-commit or Husky if needed); document usage in README; ensure CI can run the same checks.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run `pre-commit run --all-files` to validate hooks; introduce intentionally misformatted files and ensure hooks fail and auto-fix where applicable; attempt a commit with a non-conforming message and confirm it is blocked; run `npm run lint` and Python linters to verify no errors.

subtasks.title: Configure CI workflows (GitHub Actions) for linting and tests
subtasks.description: Add CI pipelines for backend and frontend to run on pushes/PRs with caching, artifacts, and coverage.
subtasks.details: Create .github/workflows/backend.yml to set up Python (3.11), install deps (cache pip), run pre-commit, unit tests, and upload coverage (e.g., to Codecov) on push/pull_request; create frontend.yml to set up Node (20.x), install deps with npm ci (cache), run lint, tests, and build; define concurrency groups and required checks for main branch; add status badges to README; optionally add a workflow to validate PR titles against Conventional Commits.
subtasks.testStrategy: Open a draft PR to trigger workflows and verify all jobs pass; inspect workflow logs for cache hits and coverage upload; test a failing lint or test to ensure CI blocks merges; enable branch protection requiring the CI checks to pass before merging.

tasks.title: Database Schema Design
tasks.description: Design and implement the PostgreSQL database schema for users, songs, and songlists.
tasks.details: Create tables for Users, Songs, Songlists, Songlist_Songs, and User_Preferences. Define primary keys, foreign keys, and necessary indexes. Use SQLAlchemy for ORM mapping in the backend.
tasks.testStrategy: Run database migration scripts and verify the schema using database inspection tools. Ensure all tables and relationships are correctly established.

subtasks.title: Requirements, ERD, and Naming Conventions
subtasks.description: Capture detailed requirements, model entities/relations, and define schema/naming conventions.
subtasks.details:
Scope: Users, Songs, Songlists, Songlist_Songs (junction with position), User_Preferences (1:1 with Users).
Key attributes:
- users: id (uuid), email (citext), display_name (text), created_at, updated_at
- songs: id (uuid), title (text), artist (text), album (text), duration_seconds (int), metadata (jsonb), created_at, updated_at
- songlists: id (uuid), owner_id (uuid), name (text), description (text), is_public (bool), created_at, updated_at
- songlist_songs: id (uuid), songlist_id (uuid), song_id (uuid), position (int), added_at (timestamptz)
- user_preferences: user_id (uuid pk), prefs (jsonb), updated_at
Conventions:
- snake_case table/column names; singular table names: users, songs, songlists, songlist_songs, user_preferences
- Constraint/index naming: pk_<table>, fk_<table>__<col>__<reftable>, uq_<table>__<cols>, ix_<table>__<cols>, ck_<table>__<name>
- Timestamps: timestamptz with default now(); app-managed onupdate for updated_at
Deliverables: ERD diagram (PNG/DBML), conventions doc, attribute/type matrix.
Acceptance criteria (data integrity): ERD reflects exact relationships (1:N users->songlists; M:N songlists<->songs via junction; 1:1 users->user_preferences). All required attributes and nullability documented; naming conventions approved and referenced by migrations/ORM.

subtasks.title: Alembic Base Setup and Migration Strategy
subtasks.description: Initialize Alembic, configure metadata naming conventions, and define migration workflow.
subtasks.details:
Tasks:
- alembic init, configure env.py to load SQLAlchemy Base.metadata with naming_convention
- Enable required extensions via migration: CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS pgcrypto; CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS citext;
- Strategy: one base schema revision (tables), followed by constraints/indexes if split is desired; always include downgrade paths
- Autogenerate enabled; manual review required; migration IDs use message slugs
- Envs: online/offline support; version_table schema default 'public'
Acceptance criteria: alembic upgrade head and downgrade base succeed on fresh DB; naming_convention enforced; extensions created idempotently; CI job runs migrations without prompts.

subtasks.title: Create Core Tables (DDL)
subtasks.description: Author DDL migrations for Users, Songs, Songlists, Songlist_Songs, and User_Preferences.

subtasks.title: Constraints, Foreign Keys, and Cascade Rules
subtasks.description: Define FKs, uniqueness, and check constraints with appropriate ON DELETE behavior.
subtasks.details:
Constraints:
- users: UNIQUE (email)
- songs: CHECK (duration_seconds >= 0)
- songlists: FK owner_id -> users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE
- songlist_songs: FK songlist_id -> songlists(id) ON DELETE CASCADE; FK song_id -> songs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE; CHECK (position >= 1); UNIQUE (songlist_id, song_id); UNIQUE (songlist_id, position)
- user_preferences: FK user_id -> users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE; enforce 1:1 via PK
Optional email format check: CHECK (email ~* '^[^@]+@[^@]+\.[^@]+$')
Acceptance criteria (data integrity): Inserting duplicates for unique columns fails; invalid positions or negative durations fail; deleting a user cascades to songlists and preferences; deleting songlists removes junction rows; deleting a song removes its junction rows; downgrade removes constraints cleanly.

subtasks.title: Indexes (Unique, Search, and Query-Driven)
subtasks.description: Create indexes to support uniqueness, filtering, and search patterns.

subtasks.title: SQLAlchemy Models and Relationships (with Type Hints)
subtasks.description: Implement ORM models for all tables with relationships and typing.
subtasks.details:
Models (sketch):
- Use Declarative with typing: from sqlalchemy.orm import Mapped, mapped_column, relationship
- class User: id: Mapped[UUID]; email: Mapped[str]; display_name: Mapped[Optional[str]]; songlists: Mapped[list[Songlist]] = relationship(back_populates='owner', cascade='all, delete-orphan'); preferences: Mapped['UserPreferences'] = relationship(uselist=False, back_populates='user', cascade='all, delete-orphan')
- class Song: id, title, artist, album, duration_seconds, metadata; songlists: Mapped[list['SonglistSong']] = relationship(back_populates='song', cascade='all, delete-orphan')
- class Songlist: id, owner_id, name, ...; owner: relationship('User', back_populates='songlists'); items: Mapped[list['SonglistSong']] = relationship(back_populates='songlist', cascade='all, delete-orphan', order_by='SonglistSong.position')
- class SonglistSong (association object): id, songlist_id, song_id, position, added_at; song: relationship('Song', back_populates='songlists'); songlist: relationship('Songlist', back_populates='items')
- class UserPreferences: user_id PK, prefs (dict[str, Any]), updated_at; user: relationship('User', back_populates='preferences')
- Configure __tablename__, indexes via __table_args__ to match naming_convention
Acceptance criteria: ORM reflects DDL (columns, nullability, constraints). Relationship cascades align with FKs. Type hints pass mypy basic checks. SQLAlchemy can create and query relationships (add items with positions) without violating constraints.

subtasks.title: Seed/Sample Data and Fixtures
subtasks.description: Provide seed script and test fixtures with realistic sample data.
subtasks.details:
Deliverables:
- scripts/seed.py: inserts N users, M songs, K songlists; populates songlist_songs with unique (songlist_id, song_id) and sequential position; creates default user_preferences per user
- Optional Alembic data revision for minimal bootstrap records (e.g., admin user)
- Pytest fixtures: db_engine, db_session, seed_data factory for integration tests
Acceptance criteria: Seed runs idempotently (clears or upserts as appropriate) in non-prod. All FKs and unique constraints satisfied. Basic queries return expected counts (e.g., each songlist has 5+ songs).

subtasks.title: Validation and Migration Tests (Upgrade/Downgrade) + Performance Smoke
subtasks.description: Write tests to validate schema integrity, migrations, and basic performance.
subtasks.details:
Tests:
- Migration cycle: upgrade -> seed -> downgrade -> upgrade; verify no residual objects
- Integrity: uniques (users.email), checks (position>=1, duration>=0), FKs/cascades (deleting user cascades songlists/preferences; deleting songlist removes junction rows)
- ORM: create/read/update/delete via models, relationship loading and ordering by position
- Search index smoke: EXPLAIN analyze on title/artist search shows GIN index usage
- Performance: On sample dataset (e.g., 10k songs), typical queries under 50ms on dev machine; no sequential scans for indexed filters
Acceptance criteria: All tests pass in CI. Upgrade and downgrade succeed. EXPLAIN plans show index usage. Data integrity enforced by constraints and ORM prevents invalid state.

tasks.title: User Authentication System
tasks.description: Implement JWT-based user authentication with secure password handling.
tasks.details: Use Flask-JWT-Extended for JWT handling and bcrypt for password hashing. Implement registration, login, and password reset endpoints. Store user credentials securely in the database.
tasks.testStrategy: Write unit tests for authentication endpoints. Verify JWT tokens are issued and validated correctly. Test password hashing and storage security.

subtasks.title: Security decisions: JWT lifetimes, rotation, and storage strategy
subtasks.description: Define and document the core security configuration for JWT usage and token storage.
subtasks.details:
Decide and document:
- JWT algorithm HS256 with a 256-bit SECRET_KEY from environment; include iss, sub, iat, nbf, exp, jti, and roles claims; 30s clock skew leeway.
- Access token TTL: 15 minutes; Refresh token TTL: 7 days.
- Refresh token rotation on every refresh; enable reuse detection and compromise response (revoke all existing refresh tokens for the user, require re-auth).
- Token storage and transport: issue tokens in JSON response using Authorization: Bearer for clients; document guidance for web clients to prefer HttpOnly, Secure cookies if needed (server can optionally set cookies behind a flag).
- Server-side revocation store: DB table for jti with indexes (user_id, jti, token_type, expires_at, revoked_at, reason); implement Flask-JWT-Extended callbacks to check revocation.
- CORS and cookie settings: SameSite=Lax/Strict when cookies enabled, Secure and HttpOnly; restrict allowed origins.
Acceptance Criteria:
- A SECURITY.md and config module with the above decisions exist; all values configurable via env vars.
- Tokens include jti and exp and are rejected when expired or revoked.
- Storage strategy and rotation behavior are unambiguously specified for implementation and testing.

subtasks.title: Password policy and bcrypt configuration
subtasks.description: Define password requirements and configure bcrypt hashing parameters.
subtasks.details:
Implement:
- Password policy: min length 12; require uppercase, lowercase, digit, and special character; disallow email reuse; reject common passwords (use a lightweight top-10k list or zxcvbn score >= 3 if available).
- Bcrypt configuration: bcrypt.gensalt(rounds=12) configurable via env; use constant-time comparisons; include per-hash salt from bcrypt.
- Secure storage: store only bcrypt hashes; never store plaintext; ensure unique index on user email.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Creating a user stores a bcrypt hash (starts with $2) with configured cost.
- Weak or common passwords are rejected with clear error messages.
- Verification uses constant-time compare and passes unit tests.

subtasks.title: Registration endpoint with email uniqueness and validation
subtasks.description: Implement /auth/register with input validation and secure password handling.
subtasks.details:
Implement POST /auth/register:
- Request: { email, password, display_name? } with schema validation; normalize and validate email format.
- Enforce email uniqueness (conflict returns 409) and rate-limit registrations per IP.
- Hash password with bcrypt; store created_at/updated_at; default role=user.
- Response: 201 with minimal user info (id, email, created_at); do not auto-issue tokens.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Duplicate emails return 409; invalid input returns 400 with field errors.
- DB stores only bcrypt hashes; no plaintext secrets in logs.
- Endpoint covered by unit tests.

subtasks.title: Login endpoint with throttling/rate limiting and token issuance
subtasks.description: Implement /auth/login with credential verification, rate limits, and JWT issuance.
subtasks.details:
Implement POST /auth/login:
- Request: { email, password }.
- Rate limits: e.g., 5/min per IP and 10/hour per account; exponential backoff on repeated failures.
- On success: issue access and refresh tokens per security decisions; include roles claim; return JSON { access_token, refresh_token, expires_in }.
- On failure: return 401 with generic message; use constant-time checks; log suspicious activity.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Tokens contain jti, exp, sub, and roles; validate via Flask-JWT-Extended.
- Rate limits enforced and tested; successful login returns 200 with both tokens.
- No sensitive error leakage (e.g., user enumeration).

subtasks.title: Refresh, logout, and token revocation strategy implementation
subtasks.description: Implement /auth/refresh, /auth/logout, and revocation checks with refresh rotation and reuse detection.
subtasks.details:
Implement:
- POST /auth/refresh: requires valid refresh token; rotate refresh token; persist new refresh jti; revoke old one; detect reuse and mark session compromised (revoke all tokens for user) and respond 401.
- POST /auth/logout: revoke current access and refresh tokens; optionally provide /auth/logout-all to revoke all user tokens.
- Revocation callbacks: integrate with Flask-JWT-Extended to check jti against revocation store for both access and refresh tokens.
- Index revocation table for performance and TTL cleanup job.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Old refresh tokens cannot be reused after rotation (tested).
- After logout, access token is rejected on protected endpoints; reuse detection triggers compromise workflow.
- Revocation checks run on every authenticated request.

subtasks.title: Password reset flow (email adapter) and change password endpoint
subtasks.description: Implement secure password reset via emailed token and authenticated password change.
subtasks.details:
Implement:
- POST /auth/request-password-reset: accept email; respond 200 regardless of existence; generate single-use, time-bound reset token (store hashed token with user_id, expires_at, used_at); send via email adapter interface; rate-limit requests.
- POST /auth/reset-password: verify token and expiration; enforce password policy; update bcrypt hash; invalidate all active tokens for the user; delete/mark used reset tokens.
- POST /auth/change-password (auth required): verify current password; enforce policy; update hash; revoke all tokens (require re-login).
Acceptance Criteria:
- No account enumeration via responses or timing.
- Reset tokens are single-use, short-lived (e.g., 1 hour), and stored hashed; all user tokens revoked after password change/reset.
- Flow covered by tests, including token expiry and replay rejection.

subtasks.title: Role and claims scaffolding for future authorization
subtasks.description: Add role storage and include claims in JWTs, plus basic decorators for role checks.
subtasks.details:
Implement:
- Extend user model to include role (e.g., user, admin) and optional custom claims field.
- Inject roles claim into JWTs at issuance; add helper to refresh claims.
- Provide @roles_required(['admin']) decorator and sample protected endpoint for demonstration.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Issued tokens contain roles claim; protected sample endpoint returns 403 for insufficient role and 200 for admin in tests.
- Minimal migration and backfill strategy documented.

subtasks.title: Tests: unit, integration, and threat-model checks
subtasks.description: Comprehensive tests covering endpoints, token lifecycle, storage security, and abuse cases.
subtasks.details:
Implement tests with pytest and Flask test client:
- Unit tests: validators, bcrypt hashing/verification, JWT claim contents, revocation lookup.
- Integration tests: register/login/refresh/logout, rotation and reuse detection, password reset and change flows, role-protected routes, rate-limiting behavior (with time mocking), token expiry (freezegun).
- Security checks: ensure no plaintext password storage, env-based secrets required, tokens rejected when expired/revoked, deny "none" algorithm.
- Threat model checklist: enumerate key risks (token theft, fixation, replay, brute-force) and mitigation verification.
Acceptance Criteria:
- All tests pass in CI; coverage >= 85% for auth modules.
- Explicit tests verify token issuance/validation and secure storage properties.

subtasks.title: Documentation and client usage examples
subtasks.description: Produce API docs, examples, and guidance for secure client token handling.
subtasks.details:
Deliverables:
- OpenAPI/Swagger docs for /auth/register, /auth/login, /auth/refresh, /auth/logout, /auth/request-password-reset, /auth/reset-password, /auth/change-password.
- Example flows (curl and Python) for registration, login, refresh rotation, logout-all, password reset, and role-protected access.
- Token lifecycle diagram and guidance on storage (Authorization header vs HttpOnly cookies), error handling patterns, and rate-limit backoff.
- Postman collection and README updates.
Acceptance Criteria:
- A developer can complete full auth flows using examples.
- Docs clearly state token issuance/validation expectations and secure storage recommendations.

tasks.title: Basic Flask API Setup
tasks.description: Set up the core REST API endpoints for user and song management.
tasks.details: Create a Flask application with endpoints for CRUD operations on users and songs. Implement basic error handling and input validation.
tasks.testStrategy: Use Postman or similar tools to test API endpoints. Write integration tests to ensure endpoints function as expected.

subtasks.title: Application factory and environment-based configuration
subtasks.description: Implement create_app with env-specific config and register core extensions.
subtasks.details:
Scope:
- Add app factory: create_app(env=None) selecting DevelopmentConfig, TestingConfig, ProductionConfig via APP_ENV/FLASK_ENV.
- Configure: SECRET_KEY, SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI, SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS=False, JWT_SECRET_KEY (from Task 3), JSON_SORT_KEYS=False, PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS=True, default pagination limits.
- Initialize extensions: SQLAlchemy, Marshmallow, Flask-Migrate, CORS, logging (structured with request-id), and optionally JWT (do not enforce auth yet).
- Set API base prefix '/api/v1'; add simple '/api/health' endpoint.
Deliverables:
- config.py with config classes; app/__init__.py with create_app; extensions.py for initialized instances; .env.example.
Acceptance Criteria:
- create_app returns a Flask app with correct env config (TestingConfig uses in-memory SQLite and TESTING=True).
- App boots and GET /api/health returns 200 JSON {"status":"ok"}.
- Extensions are registered without runtime errors; URL prefixing works for '/api/v1/*'.

subtasks.title: Blueprints for users and songs with routing conventions
subtasks.description: Define versioned blueprints and RESTful routes for users and songs.
subtasks.details:
Scope:
- Create blueprints: users_bp (prefix '/api/v1/users'), songs_bp (prefix '/api/v1/songs').
- Define CRUD routes: GET '' (list), POST '' (create), GET '<int:id>' (retrieve), PUT/PATCH '<int:id>' (update), DELETE '<int:id>' (delete).
- Establish route names (e.g., users.list_users) and consistent ID param naming ('user_id', 'song_id').
- Register blueprints in create_app; provide temporary stub handlers returning JSON placeholders until CRUD is implemented in Subtask 4.7.
Deliverables:

subtasks.title: Global error handlers with RFC 7807 problem+json responses
subtasks.description: Centralize error handling and standardize JSON error contract.
subtasks.details:
Scope:
- Implement error handlers for: HTTPException (use code), Marshmallow ValidationError (422), SQLAlchemy IntegrityError (409), NotFound (404), generic Exception (500).
- Response format: application/problem+json with fields: type (URI), title, status, detail, instance (request path), correlation_id, and errors (field-level issues map) when applicable.
- Add request ID middleware (X-Request-ID; generate if missing) and include in logs and error responses.
- Map unknown routes to 404 problem+json.
Deliverables:
- app/errors.py with handler registrations; middleware to attach correlation_id; documentation of error contract with examples.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Any raised HTTPException returns application/problem+json with correct status and headers.
- Validation errors produce 422 with errors map; IntegrityError returns 409 with conflict detail.
- Responses include correlation_id and instance; content-type is application/problem+json.

subtasks.title: Input validation schemas and response models
subtasks.description: Create Marshmallow schemas for users/songs and decorators to validate/serialize.
subtasks.details:
Scope:
- Schemas: UserCreate(email, username, password), UserUpdate(optional fields), UserOut(id, email, username, created_at); SongCreate(title, artist, tuning?, difficulty?), SongUpdate, SongOut(id, title, artist, created_at).
- Constraints: email format, username [a-z0-9_]{3,30}, password length>=8, title required; coerce/strip strings.
- List envelope schema: { items: [...], meta: { page, per_page, total, pages, sort, order } }.
- Implement decorators/helpers: validate_request(schema) -> parsed data on g; serialize_response(schema or envelope) -> consistent output.
- Ensure sensitive fields (password) never serialized in responses.
Deliverables:
- app/schemas/user.py, app/schemas/song.py; app/utils/validation.py decorators; schema docs.
Acceptance Criteria:
- Invalid payloads yield 422 problem+json with field-level errors; valid payloads pass data to handlers.
- Successful responses conform to output schemas; no password or sensitive data in any response.

subtasks.title: Pagination and sorting utilities

subtasks.details:
Scope:

- Sorting: parse_sort(args, allowed_fields) supporting 'sort' and 'order' or a '-field' syntax; validate allowed fields per resource.
- SQLAlchemy integration: apply_pagination(query) returning items and total; build Link header (first, prev, next, last) and meta object.
- Validation errors surface via problem+json (422) with clear messages; unknown sort fields rejected.
Deliverables:
- app/utils/pagination.py with parsing, SQLAlchemy helpers, and header/meta builders; usage examples in docstrings.
Acceptance Criteria:

- Invalid pagination/sort inputs return 422 problem+json with errors map; defaults apply when params omitted.

subtasks.title: Implement Service/Repository Layer with SQLAlchemy

Repository/service responsibilities:

- Deleting removes row from DB and related associations per schema; subsequent fetch raises NoResultFound.

subtasks.title: Integrate Validation and Centralized Error Mapping
subtasks.description: Apply schema validation and implement a unified error handler to map exceptions to API errors.
subtasks.details:
Validation:
- Use Marshmallow to load and validate request bodies and query params; reject unknown fields.
Error handling:
- Central handler mapping:
  - Schema validation errors -> 422 Unprocessable Entity with {error: {code: "validation_error", message, details: {field: [messages]}}}.
  - SQLAlchemy NoResultFound -> 404 Not Found with code "not_found".
  - IntegrityError -> 409 Conflict with code "conflict" and DB constraint info (redacted/safe).
  - JWT/authorization failures -> 401 Unauthorized or 403 Forbidden with codes "unauthorized"/"forbidden".
  - Malformed JSON -> 400 Bad Request with code "bad_request".
- Ensure consistent error envelope and correlation id logging.
Acceptance criteria:
- Invalid payloads and query params yield 422 with field-level messages.
- Missing/invalid JWT yields 401 with WWW-Authenticate header.
- Forbidden operations yield 403; non-existent resources yield 404.
- Integrity errors yield 409; responses never expose raw SQL or stack traces in production mode.

subtasks.title: Add Pagination, Filtering, and Sorting Primitives
subtasks.description: Implement safe query building for list endpoint with pagination, filters, and sortable columns.
subtasks.details:
Capabilities:
- Pagination: page/per_page via offset/limit; cap per_page at 100; include total and total_pages.
- Sorting: whitelist columns [title, artist, created_at]; support asc/desc; default created_at desc; stable ordering.
- Filtering: title and artist case-insensitive substring (ILIKE %q%), genre exact match, owner_id exact, is_public boolean.
- Query builder composes filters and sorting safely (no SQL injection), leveraging SQLAlchemy column references.
Acceptance criteria:
- GET /songs returns correct counts and items for various page/per_page inputs and includes meta fields.
- Sorting order is applied as requested; invalid sort fields/order rejected via 422.
- Filters reduce result set appropriately and can be combined with pagination.
- Performance: listing executes a bounded number of queries (no N+1), and COUNT is accurate.
<info added on 2025-10-04T14:07:04.454Z>
Enhancements:
- Added pagination.py with PaginationInfo, PaginatedResult, AdvancedPagination (offset and cursor), PaginationBuilder, and PageCache (LRU). Cursor-based pagination enables efficient traversal with stable ordering; offset-based pagination continues to support page/per_page (capped at 100) with total and pages.
- Extended filter primitives to support user scope (owner_id, is_public), genre, title/artist ILIKE, and numeric range filters for difficulty, year, and rating. Cross-field validation rejects ranges where min > max.
- Introduced schemas to support advanced querying and operations: SongQueryParams, AdvancedSearchParams, BulkUpdateSchema, BulkDeleteSchema, and FilterOptionsSchema.
- Added specialized query builders: get_popular_songs (views desc), get_top_rated_songs (rating desc), get_recent_songs (created_at desc), plus artist- and genre-scoped retrieval with pagination.
- Implemented transactional bulk operations (bulk update/delete) using whitelisted columns and safe SQLAlchemy expressions.
- Exposed endpoints powered by these primitives: /songs/popular, /songs/top-rated, /songs/recent, /songs/filter-options, /songs/advanced-search, /songs/bulk-update, /songs/bulk-delete, /songs/artist/<name>, /songs/genre/<name>.
- Performance: all filtering/sorting is database-level; optional cursor mode for large datasets; bounded query count with no N+1; LRU caching for paginated results with configurable size.

Updated acceptance criteria:
- Offset and cursor pagination both return correct items and metadata (has_next/prev and next/prev pointers). Invalid cursors/params yield 422 via centralized error mapping.
- Range filters (year, difficulty, rating) reduce results correctly, enforce min  max, and combine with other filters and pagination.
- Sorting remains restricted to supported fields and order; invalid sort rejected with 422; ordering is stable and deterministic across pages.
- Specialized endpoints return correctly ordered results: popular by views, top-rated by rating, recent by created_at; artist/genre endpoints paginate correctly.
- Bulk update/delete are atomic; partial failures roll back and return structured errors.
- Filter options endpoint returns distinct genres, artists, albums, and years, scoped appropriately.
- Listing and specialized queries execute within a bounded number of queries and produce accurate counts; cursor mode avoids unnecessary full COUNT scans.

subtasks.title: Implement Authorization Hooks (Owner/Admin Ready)
subtasks.description: Add authorization checks for create, read, update, and delete actions using JWT and role/ownership rules.
subtasks.details:
Auth model and rules:
- Authentication: use JWT; user extracted from token; assume user.is_admin boolean is available.
- Create: authenticated users only; owner_id set to current user id.
- Read single: public songs accessible to anyone; private songs (is_public=false) only to owner or admin -> otherwise 403.
- List: anonymous users see only public songs; authenticated users by default see public songs; support scope filter: mine (only their songs), public (only is_public=true), all (admin only, else 403).
- Update/Delete: only owner or admin may modify/delete; enforce both at endpoint decorator/middleware and in service layer.
Implementation:
- Authorization decorator/util (e.g., can_manage_song) and checks inside service methods as defense in depth.
- Ensure forbidden reasons are mapped to 403 via error handler.
Acceptance criteria:
- Unauthorized access to protected endpoints returns 401; insufficient privileges return 403.
- Owners can update/delete their songs; non-owners cannot.
- Admin can manage any song.
- List endpoint enforces scope semantics as specified.

subtasks.title: Add PostgreSQL full-text search vector and GIN index for Songs
subtasks.description: Create a tsvector search column for the Songs table combining title and artist, and index it to enable fast full-text search.
subtasks.details:
Implementation approach (Alembic migration + SQLAlchemy):
1) Create an Alembic migration that:
   - Ensures required extensions exist (optional but recommended):
     - op.execute("CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS pg_trgm")  // optional, not strictly needed for FTS
     - op.execute("CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS unaccent")  // optional if you want diacritic-insensitive search
   - Adds a STORED generated column (PostgreSQL 12+):
     op.execute("""
       ALTER TABLE songs
       ADD COLUMN search_vector tsvector GENERATED ALWAYS AS (
         setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(title, '')), 'A') ||
         setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(artist, '')), 'B')
       ) STORED
     """);
     // Use 'simple' config to avoid stemming of names; switch to 'english' if desired.
   - Creates a GIN index on search_vector:
     op.execute("CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_songs_search_vector ON songs USING GIN (search_vector)");
   - If STORED generated columns are not available in your environment, fall back to:
     - Add a plain tsvector column search_vector
     - Backfill: UPDATE songs SET search_vector = setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(title, '')), 'A') || setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(artist, '')), 'B');
     - Add trigger to keep it updated:
       op.execute("CREATE FUNCTION songs_search_vector_update() RETURNS trigger LANGUAGE plpgsql AS $$ BEGIN NEW.search_vector := setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(NEW.title, '')), 'A') || setweight(to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(NEW.artist, '')), 'B'); RETURN NEW; END $$;");
       op.execute("CREATE TRIGGER trg_songs_search_vector BEFORE INSERT OR UPDATE OF title, artist ON songs FOR EACH ROW EXECUTE FUNCTION songs_search_vector_update();");
     - Create the same GIN index as above.
2) Update the SQLAlchemy model (if needed) to include the search_vector column as a deferred/read-only column for query use; it doesnt need to be exposed via API.
3) Run migration and verify the index exists.
subtasks.testStrategy: Post-migration verification: SELECT to_regclass('public.idx_songs_search_vector') should not be NULL. Seed a few songs, run an EXPLAIN on a sample FTS query (WHERE search_vector @@ websearch_to_tsquery('simple', 'beatles')) and confirm the GIN index is used.

subtasks.title: Implement search service/repository using PostgreSQL full-text search
subtasks.description: Create a backend function that executes ranked full-text searches over Songs by title and artist, with pagination.
subtasks.details:
Implementation approach (Flask + SQLAlchemy):
1) Add a function search_songs(q: str, limit: int = 20, offset: int = 0) -> list[Song], and optionally return a tuple (results, count_estimate) if you decide to include counts later.
2) Build a tsquery with websearch_to_tsquery('simple', :q) to support AND/OR, quotes, and prefix via trailing '*'.
3) Query pattern (SQLAlchemy pseudocode):
   ts_query = func.websearch_to_tsquery('simple', bindparam('q'))
   rank = func.ts_rank_cd(Song.search_vector, ts_query)
   stmt = (
     sa.select(Song, rank.label('rank'))
       .where(Song.search_vector.op('@@')(ts_query))
       .order_by(sa.desc(rank), Song.title.asc(), Song.id.asc())
       .limit(sa.bindparam('limit'))
       .offset(sa.bindparam('offset'))
   )
   Use bound params to prevent SQL injection.
4) Enforce parameter caps: limit min=1, max=50; offset >= 0.
5) Consider weighting already encoded in search_vector; rank with ts_rank_cd is sufficient. If you did not weight in the vector, pass weights to ts_rank_cd as needed.
6) Return a lightweight DTO per song (id, title, artist, and optionally rank) for the API layer.
subtasks.testStrategy: Unit tests against a test DB: seed songs with overlapping words across title and artist to verify ranking (title-weighted > artist-weighted). Test: simple term, multi-term AND/OR, quoted phrases, trailing '*' for prefix. Verify pagination and deterministic ordering for ties.

subtasks.title: Define API contract and validate request/response for song search
subtasks.description: Specify and validate the search endpoint contract, including required query parameter q and pagination parameters, with clear error handling.
subtasks.details:
Implementation approach:
1) Endpoint: GET /songs/search
2) Query parameters:
   - q (required, string, 1..200 chars)
   - limit (optional, int, default 20, 1..50)
   - offset (optional, int, default 0, >=0)
3) Response body (200):
   {
     "results": [{"id": ..., "title": "...", "artist": "...", "rank": 0.0}],
     "limit": 20,
     "offset": 0,
     "count": null
   }
   Note: count can be omitted or null for simplicity; add later if needed.
4) Errors:
   - 400 for missing/empty q or invalid params (non-integer limit/offset, out of range)
5) Validation: Use Marshmallow or Pydantic-like schema for parsing and validating query params; clamp/cap values; trim q; reject queries that are whitespace-only.
6) Document in OpenAPI/Swagger (path, parameters, responses).
subtasks.testStrategy: Contract tests: validate 400 on invalid q, negative offset, excessive limit. Validate schema of 200 response. Include an OpenAPI validation step if available.

subtasks.title: Implement GET /songs/search endpoint in Flask
subtasks.description: Create the Flask route/controller that validates input, invokes the search service, and returns JSON results.
subtasks.details:
Implementation approach:
1) Add route in the songs blueprint/module: @bp.get('/songs/search').
2) Parse and validate query params using the schema from 7.3. On validation error, return 400 with message and details.
3) Call search_songs(q, limit, offset) from 7.2. Map returned rows to JSON objects (id, title, artist, optional rank rounded to 4 decimals).
4) Return 200 JSON: {results, limit, offset}.
5) Logging: log query terms and pagination (without PII). Add basic timing metrics to observe performance.
6) Security/performance safeguards: enforce cap on limit, and short-circuit empty q. No authentication required unless product requires it; if auth is required later, add @jwt_required(optional=True) as needed without altering core logic.
subtasks.testStrategy: Integration tests with Flask test client: seed a few songs and hit /songs/search. Verify 200 path returns expected ordering, 400 on invalid input, pagination behavior, and absence of server errors. Optionally test JSON serialization and CORS headers if applicable.

subtasks.title: End-to-end search tests and performance smoke checks
subtasks.description: Verify correctness across realistic datasets and ensure the GIN index is used so queries remain fast.
subtasks.details:
Implementation approach:
1) E2E tests (pytest): spin up a test Postgres with migrations applied. Seed 50100 songs with diverse titles/artists.
2) Correctness scenarios: search by exact title word, artist name, multi-word queries, quoted phrases, punctuation, case-insensitivity, prefix (provide trailing '*'). Validate that top results include expected songs and ranking is sensible.
3) Pagination scenarios: limit/offset correctness and stable ordering across pages.
4) Performance smoke: ensure cold query returns in <150 ms on test hardware and <30 ms warm (adjust thresholds per environment). Use EXPLAIN ANALYZE in a diagnostic test (not part of CI by default) to confirm GIN index usage.
5) Regression harness: add tests for edge cases (empty results, very long q rejected, high Unicode).
subtasks.testStrategy: Run the test suite in CI against a Postgres service. Optionally collect EXPLAIN plans and log them for manual inspection. Use a seeded dataset to assert deterministic outcomes.
